Instruction: Prepare the Ingredients
Whisk Eggs: In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs until well combined.
Combine Dashi and Seasonings:  In a separate bowl or measuring cup, whisk together the dashi stock, light soy sauce, mirin, and a pinch of salt.
Strain (Optional): For an extra smooth texture, you can strain the dashi-seasoning mixture through a fine-mesh sieve to remove any bits of kombu or bonito flakes (if using pre-made dashi).
Incorporate Dashi Mixture
Slowly Add Dashi: Slowly whisk the dashi mixture into the beaten eggs, combining well. Be careful not to overmix.
Strain (Optional)
Optional Straining: Strain the egg-dashi mixture through a fine-mesh sieve to remove any air bubbles for a smoother custard (optional).
Prepare the Steamers

Fill Steamer Bowls: Divide your chosen fillings (mushrooms, shrimp, chicken, peas, bamboo shoots) among individual heat-resistant bowls or ramekins. **Optional:** Add a spoonful of cooked rice to the bottom of each bowl.
Pour Egg Mixture: Carefully pour the strained egg-dashi mixture evenly into the bowls, filling them to about Â¾ full.
Steam the Chawanmushi
Prepare a Steamer:  In a pot or steamer, bring a few inches of water to a simmer.

Steam the Custard: Place the bowls in the steamer, ensuring they are not touching the simmering water. Cover the steamer and steam the chawanmushi for 12-15 minutes, or until the custard is set and cooked through. The edges will be slightly firm, but the center may still jiggle slightly.
Serve and Enjoy

Garnish and Serve: Once cooked, carefully remove the bowls from the steamer. Garnish with a sprig of mitsuba (Japanese parsley) and a sprinkle of shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven-spice powder) for an extra kick (optional). Serve hot and enjoy!
Tips:
Use a chopstick to gently poke the center of the custard to check for doneness. If it's still runny, steam for a few more minutes.
Be careful not to overcook the custard, as it will become tough.

Leftover chawanmushi can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 1 day. The texture may become slightly firmer upon reheating. Reheat gently in a steamer or microwave until warmed through.
